child.pub-comments: Greenberg notes that “Perhaps Ganawuri belongs here also. There are a number of presumably 'Semi-Bantu' languages from this area for which no published materials exist” (12)

child.pub-comments: Greenberg writes that there are some indications that Adamawa and Eastern Branch are part of the same branch, and Gbaya, in particular, “displays evidence of affiliation with the Adamawa branch” (12)

child.pub-comments: Greenberg notes that these languages were “recently reported as spoken in Portuguese Guinea. See J. Basso Margues, Familiaridade idiomatica entre Cobianas e Cassangas (Boletim Cultural da Guine Portuguesa, vol. 2, pp. 875-914, 1947)” (10)

child.pub-comments: Greenberg writes, “Mekyibo and Abure are put together by Westermann along with my groups 7, 8, 9 to form an Ivory Coast Lagoon subdivision of his Kwa family” (10) (Greenberg numbers the Western, Central, and Eastern Ivory Coast Lagoon subgroups as 7, 8, and 9, respectively)
